Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Soccer Coach position at North High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Head Boys Soccer Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At North High School, the Head Boys Soccer Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Head Boys Soccer Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Head Boys Soccer Coach at North High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach role at Yuba City High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Yuba City High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Yuba City High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The YCHS Boys Volleyball Varsity Assistant Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Yuba City High School.

Job.JobTitle: RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach at River Valley High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at River Valley High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The RVHS Varsity Girls Volleyball Head Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at River Valley High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball at Glinda Medina is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Glinda Medina, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Glinda Medina operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Glinda Medina with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach - Girls' Basketball role at Glinda Medina.

The Track and Field Coach role at Graham Middle School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Track and Field Coach is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Graham Middle School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Track and Field Coach listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Track and Field Coach encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Track and Field Coach follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Graham Middle School, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Track and Field Coach at Graham Middle School, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 position at Mary Martinez is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 at Mary Martinez sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Mary Martinez, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the DNHS Head Volleyball Coach 26/27 position at Mary Martinez is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The ATHLETIC TRAINER at Bassett Unified is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the ATHLETIC TRAINER plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Bassett Unified reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The ATHLETIC TRAINER expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the ATHLETIC TRAINER supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the ATHLETIC TRAINER may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Bassett Unified. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at San Joaquin Delta College are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At San Joaquin Delta College, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool at San Joaquin Delta College, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Track Head Coach role at Calipatria Unified emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Varsity Track Head Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Calipatria Unified, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Varsity Track Head Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Calipatria Unified at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Varsity Track Head Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Varsity Track Head Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Varsity Track Head Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Calipatria Unified.

Basketball Coach role at Lewisville ISD is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Lewisville ISD, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. Basketball Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. Overall, the Any Core or CTE Teacher/Asst. Football and Asst. Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 at Brownsville Independent School District sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Brownsville Independent School District, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Athletic Trainer Pool 2025 position at Brownsville Independent School District is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
Position Type: Athletics/Campus Athletic Coordinator/Head Football Coach - Middle School
Date Posted: 10/7/2025
Location: Polk Middle School
Job Title: Head Football Coach/MS Athletic Coordinator Reports to: Principal Dept./School: Assigned Campus Wage/Hour Status: Exempt Pay Grade: AP 2 – 187Days Date Revised: April 24, 2024
Primary Purpose: To help each student participate in high school athletics, achieve a high degree of skill and appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship and an increased level of self-esteem.
Qualifications: Education/Certification: Minimum of a bachelor’s degree. Demonstrated skill and competence in planning, organizing, and directing student athletic activities. Valid Texas teaching certificate or such other credentials as may be required by the State Board for Educator Certification for this position.
Special Knowledge/Skills: Possess strong analytical, organizational, and leadership skills Demonstrate effective communication, public relation, and interpersonal skills.
Experience: A minimum of 4 years’ experience as a high school Varsity Offensive/Defensive play caller. High School Head Football Coaching experience preferred.
Major Responsibilities and Duties: 1. Assist the Athletic Director in coordinating the competitive sports program at the assigned high school. 2. Support all phases of the athletic program and encourage athletes to participate in every sport in which they have talent and interest. 3. Be responsible for ensuring that all rules, regulations, guidelines, and policies of TEA, UIL, and Carrollton-Farmers Branch ISD are followed at his/her campus. 4. Assist the athletic department, Human Resources department, and principal in recruiting and interviewing coaching personnel and follow required district personnel procedures to fill vacancies on the coaching staff at the high school. 5. Evaluate head coaches in each sport, athletic trainers, and all assistant football coaches and approve the evaluations of all other assistant coaches by their head coach and ensure that the evaluation process is conducted according to C-FB ISD policy. 6. Work with the principal and Athletic Director in providing information for the development of the master schedule to ensure, the most advantageous use of coaching personnel, athletic periods, conference periods and optimum utilization of facilities. 7. Prepare duty rosters, schedule, and secure working personnel for sub-varsity football games, basketball games, baseball games, track and wrestling meets, and other athletic events as needed. 8. Keep the principal and Athletic Director informed of needs and problems within the athletic program. 9. Collect, check, and forward to the athletic department the proposed schedule of interschool games and scrimmages for all sports on campus and be available to assist head coaches with scheduling, if needed. 10. Coordinate transportation request with the athletic and transportation departments for all sports on campus. 11. Work with head coaches to ensure that bid request and inventories for all sports are completed and turned in on time and receive and disperse equipment for all sports on campus. 12. Assist the principal and Athletic Director in improving and maintaining the athletic fields, gymnasiums, courts, and tracks on campus. 13. Attend all UIL District meetings with the principal and Athletic Director as a representative of the school and athletic department when requested by the administration. 14. Promote the athletic program with the media, civic groups, booster groups, parent and school organizations and assist head coaches in promoting their teams and their sports. 15. Work with the middle school, feeder school and coaches to develop lines of communication, coordination and continuity with the total high school sports program, with special emphasis on the transition from middle school and the retention of student athletes in the program. 16. Work with the administration and head coaches to find ways to reduce academic athletic ineligibility. 17. See that all coaches on campus are provided with office space, keys, office supplies, facilities, materials and equipment as needed. 18. Ensure that all coaches have a notarized UIL “Professional Acknowledgement” form on file with the Athletic Department Office. 19. Maintain necessary eligibility forms, physical exam forms, grade reports, transfer forms, and insurance information relevant to student athletes. 20. Operate the summer conditioning program. 21. Assist the Director of Athletics during summer months. 22. Set an appropriate example for athletes and co-workers in the areas of personal behavior, speech, dress, and good sportsmanship. 23. Perform all other duties as deemed necessary by the Superintendent or designee
Working Conditions: Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Ability to communicate effectively (verbal and written); interpret policy, procedures, and data; coordinate district functions; maintain emotional control under stress. District and statewide travel; occasional prolonged and irregular hours.
The foregoing statements describe the general purpose and responsibilities assigned to this job and are not an exhaustive list of all responsibilities and duties that may be assigned or skills that may be required.

Job.JobDescription:
Primary Purpose: Work under the supervision of the campus principal, Athletic Director, and Head Athletic Trainer. Responsible for the overall athletic training program for assigned middle schools (Bonham, Lamar, Travis), including prevention, care, and rehabilitation of athletic injuries and management of the athletic training room. Will work in cooperation with the high school athletic trainers and receive support from high school staff to cover events at the middle school level.
Qualifications: Education/Certification: Bachelor’s degree in Athletic Training or related field Texas Board of Athletic Trainers License (LAT) or Certification by the Board of Certification (BOC) Current CPR/AED/First Aid certification Experience: Experience working with secondary school athletes Experience managing multiple sites or schedules Knowledge of UIL regulations and Texas school athletic policies
Major Responsibilities and Duties: Assist in the planning and implementation of a comprehensive athletic injury and illness prevention program for student athletes. Attend practice sessions and athletic contests as assigned by AD, Assistant AD and Head Athletic Trainer. Be available for HOME events (7th through Varsity) as assigned. Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff. Prepare athletes for games and practices by conducting evaluations and using tape, wraps, splints, braces, & other protective devices as needed. Respond to emergencies and make quick, independent judgments about how to deal with injuries. Identify acute injuries and provide first-aid triage, including assessing injuries and deciding whether an athlete should seek further medical attention and should discontinue participation in the athletic event. Assist the Head Athletic Trainer in establishing specific procedures to be carried out by a coach or student athletic trainer in the event of a medical emergency. Compile, maintain, and file all physical and computerized reports, records, and other documents including doctor, accident, and treatment records as required. Maintain an inventory of training supplies and equipment. Assist with the organization and monitoring of UIL required physical examinations for all athletics 7-12. Assist the Head Athletic trainers with all Staff Development pertaining to athlete safety in accordance w/ State mandates and UIL Policies. Communicate utilizing the prescribed chain of command. Perform other duties assigned by the Athletic Director and Head Athletic Trainer.
Leadership Qualities: Models a Commitment to Excellence by setting direction for campus departments, utilizing innovative approaches to challenges, and achieving results by prioritizing needs, adjusting plans, and optimizing resources. Has the ability to Connect with All by building trust across campus departments and within the community, creating collaborative processes that value varying perspectives, and providing clear and transparent communication. Seeks opportunities to Invest in Growth by developing self, empowering others, and embracing reflective practices that encourages growth toward goal attainment among staff.
Supervisory Responsibilities: Direct the work of student assistants.
Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Tools/Equipment Used: Exercise equipment and devices including stationary bike, pulleys, weights, whirlpool, paraffin bath, ultrasound equipment, and cold packs; automated external defibrillator (AED) Posture: Prolonged standing; frequent kneeling/squatting, bending/stooping, pushing/pulling, and twisting Motion: Continual walking; moderate reaching Lifting: Frequently moderate lifting or carrying (15-44 pounds) Environment: Work outside (exposure to sun, heat, cold, and inclement weather) and inside; exposure to noise; exposure to biological hazards, bacteria, and communicable diseases; frequent districtwide and statewide travel Mental Demands: Maintain emotional control under stress; frequent prolonged and irregular hours

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Soccer Coach at High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Soccer Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Soccer Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Soccer Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Soccer Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.SalaryRange: Commensurate with TCISD hiring salary guide. Stipend based on sport(s) coached.

Job.JobTitle: 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher (Pool for 2026-2027 School Year)
Job.JobDescription:
The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher at Lovejoy High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Lovejoy High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Lovejoy High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Lovejoy High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the 9-12th Grade COACH/Classroom Teacher role at Lovejoy High School.

Job.JobDescription:
Plan, coordinate, and supervise all components of the athletic training program for student athletes. Work under the direction of the team physician to prevent, recognize, assess, manage, treat, and recondition athletic injuries and illnesses. Additonal pay for summer hours (summer strenth and speed program). 210 day contract.
Qualifications: Education/Certification: Bachelor's degree Valid license from the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation (TDLR) Current adult cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and automated external defibrillator (AED) certification
Special Knowledge/Skills: Knowledge of therapeutic modalities and injury prevention Ability to provide emergency care and rehabilitation for student athletic injuries Ability to instruct and supervise student athletes and assistants Strong organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills
Experience: 0 years of experience as an athletic trainer
Major Responsibilities and Duties:
1. Plan and implement a comprehensive program to prevent athletic injuries and illnesses among student athletes. 2. Provide physical conditioning training to student athletes. 3. Attend practice sessions and athletic contests and prepare athletes using protective techniques and devices as needed. 4. Provide emergency or continued care and refer athletes to physicians for definitive diagnosis and treatment. 5. Detect and resolve risks to athletes and determine whether they can continue participating in athletic events. 6. Develop and establish specific procedures to be carried out in the event of a medical emergency. 7. Provide health care information and counsel, and instruct student athletes on subject matter related to athletic training. 8. Establish and maintain effective communication with students, parents, medical and paramedical personnel, coaches, and other staff.
Rehabilitation/Reconditioning
1. Plan and implement a comprehensive rehabilitation and reconditioning program for injuries and illnesses sustained by student athletes. 2. Determine therapeutic goals and objectives for individual athletes, apply therapeutic modalities, and instruct athletes on proper use of exercise equipment. 3. Fit injured athletes with specialized equipment and oversee its use. 4. Evaluate and record the rehabilitation progress of athletes. Develop criteria for progression and return to practice and competition. 5. Follow and enforce professional, ethical, and legal parameters regarding the use of drugs and therapeutic agents for the treatment and rehabilitation of injured athletes.
Administration
1. Coordinate scheduling of athletic physical examinations and screening. 2. Select, train, and supervise student assistants. 3. Compile, maintain, and file all reports, records, and other documents, including medical, accident, and treatment records as required. 4. Maintain an inventory of training supplies and equipment to ensure a consistent supply. Requisition additional supplies as needed. 5. Follow district safety protocols and emergency procedures.
Supervisory Responsibilities:
Assist with the supervision of student athletic trainers/aides.
Working Conditions: Mental Demands/Physical Demands/Environmental Factors: Maintain emotional control under stress. Frequent district and statewide travel; prolonged and irregular hours; outdoor and indoor work; exposure to sun, heat, cold, and inclement weather.
Job.Experience: 0 years

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach at San Dieguito High School Academy is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at San Dieguito High School Academy reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 2025-2026 - Boy's Lacrosse - Junior Varsity Assistant Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at San Dieguito High School Academy. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the FOOTBALL - HEAD JV COACH - Lynbrook High School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.

The FOOTBALL - HEAD JV COACH - Lynbrook High School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Lynbrook High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Baseball, JV Assistant Coach at LAHS encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.

Job.JobTitle: Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade) at Daryl Lee is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade) are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Daryl Lee use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade) recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade) collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Athletics: Girl's Volleyball -Ione Jr High School (6th, 7th & 8th grade) maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Daryl Lee. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary The La Cañada High School Athletics Department has an opening for the Boys Varsity Head Water Polo Coach. The team practices the full year and has its competitive season in the fall, approximately August through October. The chosen candidate will be asked to start in the position as soon as background clearances are received, including fingerprinting results and tuberculosis screening.
Requirements / Qualifications Application Procedure: 1. Current LCUSD employees may submit a letter of interest to Human Resources. Outside parties may submit an electronic application through the posting on EdJoin (www.edjoin.org/lcusd). The EdJoin application should include a coaching resume, references with contact information, and at least three (3) recent letters of reference/recommendation. An introduction letter and/or coaching portfolio are welcome but not required. Letters may be addressed to:
Dr. Debra Cradduck, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources La Cañada Unified School District 4490 Cornishon Avenue La Cañada, CA 91011
2. After applications have been screened, candidates will be contacted for a personal interview with an interview panel. Interviews will be conducted in person at La Cañada High School. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Items below are required for an application to be considered: • Letter(s) of Recommendation (at least 3 current letters) • Resume (with references, including contact information)
Comments and Other Information Qualifications: 1. Experience: Two years or more of successful experience coaching high school, collegiate or elite/club water polo. 2. Licenses: Current first aid and CPR certifications.
Work Calendar: The competitive season ranges approximately August through October. The varsity head coach may be asked to work with the team year-round, including summers, for practice and strength training. The chosen candidate will assume coaching responsibilities as soon as clearance is confirmed from a background check, tuberculosis skin test reading and completion of the onboarding process.
Compensation: The stipend for this position is $4,010.00 annually, paid as a lump sum at the conclusion of the competitive season. Additional compensation is paid at a daily rate for the length of the time the team participates in CIF finals. The daily rate for CIF compensation is calculated by dividing the regular stipend by the number of days in the regular season
Benefits: This position does not meet the eligibility requirements to participate in the District's health and welfare benefits.

Job.JobTitle: Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School at Vanessa Garces is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Vanessa Garces, the Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Vanessa Garces well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Boys JV Volleyball Head Coach - Saratoga High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The JV Softball Coach role at Aaron Brooks is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the JV Softball Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Aaron Brooks, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The JV Softball Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Aaron Brooks, the JV Softball Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the JV Softball Coach at Aaron Brooks is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
STANDARDS FOR ATHLETIC TEAM COACHES
The following standards are minimum qualifications for applicants to athletic team coach positions in the Mt. Diablo Unified School District. Knowledge, training, and demonstrated competency in the following areas are required to qualify for any athletic coach position in the District.
1. Knowledge and Competencies: Knowledge and competency related to care and prevention of athletic injuries, basic first aid and emergency procedures which may be evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college-level course in the care and prevention of athletic injuries and possession of a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card. A valid sports injury certificated or first aid card, and a valid cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) card.
2. Coaching Techniques: The coach shall be knowledgeable in coaching theory and techniques in the sport or game being coached as evidenced by one or more of the following: Completion of a college course in coaching theory and techniques of the specific sport. Completion of in-service programs arranged by a school district or county office of education in the specific sport. Prior services as a head or assistant athletic coach in the specific sport. Prior participation in organized competitive athletics at high school level or above in the sport being coached.
3. Rules and Regulations in the Athletic Activity Being Coached including: Training and knowledge of the rules and regulations in the athletic activity being coached and demonstrated ability to communicate those rules and regulations in an e?ective, respectful manner which instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. The coach shall have knowledge of the rules and regulations of the North Coast Section pertaining to the sport or game being coached, the league rules, and regulations of the California Interscholastic Federation.
Additional Competencies for Non-certificated Personnel In addition to the competencies listed above, it shall be determined that a non-certificated person employed as a temporary athletic coach: Has not been convicted of any offense referred to in Education Code 44010, 44011 or 44424, or any offense involving moral turpitude or evidencing unfitness to associate with children. Is free from tuberculosis and any other contagious disease that would prohibit certif?cated teachers from teaching, as verified by a written statement, renewable every four years, from a licensed physician or other person approved by the district Has no authority to give grades to students. Shall not assume coaching duties/responsibilities prior to the District receiving fingerprint clearance from the Department of Justice.
5. Code of Ethical Conduct: Applicants for athletic team coach positions shall be expected to demonstrate knowledge, training and competency to insure compliance with the following Code of Ethical Conduct. In addition, all athletic team coaches providing supervisory or instructional services in interscholastic athletic programs shall abide by the Code of Ethical Conduct. Show respect for players, officials, other coaches and parents Respect the integrity and judgment of game officials. Establish and model fair play, sportsmanship and proper conduct. Establish player safety and welfare as the highest priority. Provide an environment that instills teamwork, commitment and discipline. Provide leadership which promotes a positive experience for the student athlete. Provide proper supervision of students at all times. Use discretion when providing constructive criticism and when reprimanding players. Maintain consistency in requiring all players to adhere to the established rules and standards of the game. Properly instruct players in the safe use of equipment. Avoid exerting undue influence on a student's decision to enroll in an athletic program at any public or private postsecondary educational institution. Avoid exerting undue influence on students to take lighter academic course(s) in order to be eligible to participate in athletics. Avoid suggesting, providing or encouraging any athlete to use non-prescriptive drugs, anabolic steroids or any substance to increase physical development or performance that is not approved by the Food and Drug Administration, U.S. Surgeon General or the American Medical Association. Avoid recruitment of athletes from other schools. Work effectively with booster groups. Work effectively with school administration.
Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required

Job.JobDescription:
The recreation coach 3 - 136581 position at University of California - San Diego provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At University of California - San Diego, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The recreation coach 3 - 136581 encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the recreation coach 3 - 136581 at University of California - San Diego is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

This positon will require daily and/or weekly duties and tasks as assigned by the head coach which require exercising discretion and independent judgment consisting of 75% instructional and 25% recruitment/administrative activities.
1. Organize and evaluate practices, training plans and intercollegiate competitions. Teach necessary skills from the basic fundamentals to the techniques and strategies of team play. 2. Promote and foster a positive team environment, appropriate behavior, and sportsmanship by team members. Responsible for the conduct of team members both on and off the field. Promote the physical and mental well-being of all program participants. 3. Responsible for the academic performance of team members including graduation from the College. Support, monitor, and evaluate the academic performance of the student-athletes participating in the sport program. Work closely with Student-Athlete Services to assist student-athletes as needed with their academic success. 4. Recruit and select qualified prospects who have the ability to compete in the classroom and athletically. Actively seek out and encourage a diverse group of prospects and assist them through the application process. Work collaboratively with Student-Athlete Services and the Admissions Office staff to qualify and process prospects in a timely and efficient manner and in accordance with all College, Conference and NCAA policies. 5. Assist in developing and implementing a public relations/ fundraising plan to promote and advance the swimming program and athletics within the College and the surrounding community. Represent the College at various on and off-campus events. Be an active participant in departmental fundraising activities. 6. Comply with all College, Conference, and NCAA rules and regulations. Know, recognize, and comply with the laws, policies, rules, and regulations governing the College and its employees, and the rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (including, but not limited to, NCAA Bylaw, Article 11 and its requirement to report all athletically-related income and benefits from sources outside of the College to the President) and of the MPSF Conference as now constituted or as may be amended in the future. Supervise and ensure that any assistants and any other employees and/or volunteers for whom you are administratively responsible comply with the aforesaid policies, rules and regulations. Ability to maintain confidentiality and use discretion. Job.JobDescription:
The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade role at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D., teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D., the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Track Coach, 6th/7th Grade at Livermore Valley Joint Unified S.D. is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The JHS Softball Coach 6-8 at Jessie Ceja is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the JHS Softball Coach 6-8 are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. Within the school, the JHS Softball Coach 6-8 collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The JHS Softball Coach 6-8 maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Jessie Ceja. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High at Monte Vista High is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Monte Vista High, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Monte Vista High operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Monte Vista High with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Coach | Cheer JV HEAD - Monte Vista High role at Monte Vista High.
